Ari J. Markenson Age 45

Scarsdale, NY | New York, NY

Mr. Markensonâ€™s legal career has been devoted to representing various health care industry clients, including providers and payers, and has specific expertise in the representation of post-acute care providers. Mr. Markenson was acknowledged as an â€œOutstanding Young Healthcare Lawyerâ€ by Nightingaleâ€™s Healthcare News in 2004. He is the Editor in Chief of The Long Term Care Facility Survey and Certification Guide, a comprehensive publication on the federal long-term care survey and certification process. He is also on the editorial advisory board of the Long-Term Care Survey Alert. He is the co-editor of the AHLA's 50 State Survey of Licensure and Certificate of Need Laws for Nursing Homes, Assisted Living, Home Health and Hospice. Mr. Markenson teaches Long Term Care Administration and Legal Aspects of Health Care Administration for the University of Maryland, University College, Graduate School of Management and Technology, in its M.S. in Health Care Administration Program and teaches Health Care in the United States and Management of Long Term Care Facilities for the New York Medical College School of Public Health in its M.P.H. and certificate programs. He is an Adjunct Associate Professor of Law at Brooklyn Law School where he teaches a health law practice workshop. Mr. Markenson speaks and publishes regularly for well-known health care organizations on topics related to health care law. Additionally, he is the Chair of and a member of the Executive Committee of the New York State Bar Association - Health Law Section and a Vice Chair of the American Health Lawyers Association, LTC-SIR Practice Group. Specialties Health care industry, Long-term care, Post-acute care, Sub-acute care, legal and regulatory compliance, requirements/conditions for participation, fraud and abuse, HIPAA, and survey, certification and enforcement, Medicare, Medicaid, managed care and private insurance reimbursement issues, administrative proceedings, acquisitions, obtaining certificate of need approval and state licensure, health care decision making and refusal of treatment issues.
